workflow.name: Automated AI media creation with MagicHour AI and GPT-4 prompt optimization
workflow.description:
This workflow automates AI-powered image and video generation using MagicHour.ai's API, enhanced by GPT-4.1 for intelligent prompt optimization. It processes webhook requests, refines prompts using AI, generates media content, and returns the final output.

## Who's it for

Content creators, marketers, social media managers, and developers who need automated AI media generation at scale. Perfect for teams building applications that require on-demand image or video creation without manual intervention.

## How it works

The workflow receives a webhook POST request containing generation parameters (type, orientation, style, duration). GPT-4.1 analyzes and optimizes the user's prompt based on the request type (image or video), then sends it to MagicHour.ai's API. The workflow monitors the generation status through polling loops, downloads the completed media, and returns it via webhook response. Error handling ensures failed requests are captured and reported.

## Requirements

- **n8n instance** (self-hosted or cloud)
- **MagicHour.ai account** with API access (Bearer token)
- **OpenAI API account** for GPT-4.1 access
- Basic understanding of webhooks and JSON

## How to set up

**Configure credentials:**
- Add MagicHour.ai Bearer token in HTTP Request nodes (ai-image-generator, text-to-video, Get Image Details, Get Video Details)
- Add OpenAI API credentials in both Generate Image Prompt and Generate video Prompt nodes

**Activate the workflow:**
- Enable the workflow to activate the webhook endpoint
- Copy the webhook URL from the Webhook trigger node

# Test the workflow:

**Download** the n8n-magichour HTML tester [Click here to download](https://github.com/inderjeetsingh21/n8n-repo/tree/main/n8n-webhook-AI-testers/n8n-magichour-ai-tester) 

For image generation, send a POST request with this structure:
```json
{
  "action": "generate",
  "type": "image",
  "parameters": {
    "name": "My Image",
    "image_count": 1,
    "orientation": "landscape",
    "style": {
      "prompt": "A serene mountain landscape at sunset",
      "tool": "realistic"
    }
  }
}
```

For video generation, use:
```json
{
  "action": "generate",
  "type": "video",
  "parameters": {
    "name": "My Video",
    "end_seconds": 5,
    "orientation": "landscape",
    "resolution": "1080p",
    "style": {
      "prompt": "A dog running through a field"
    }
  }
}
```

## How to customize the workflow

**Adjust AI prompt optimization:** Modify the system prompts in Generate Image Prompt or Generate video Prompt nodes to change how GPT-4.1 refines user inputs. Current prompts enforce strict character limits and avoid unauthorized content.

**Change polling intervals:** Modify the Wait nodes to adjust how frequently the workflow checks generation status (useful for longer video renders).

**Modify response format:** Update the Respond to Webhook node to customize the output structure sent back to the caller.

**Add multiple output formats:** Extend Download Image/Video nodes to save files to cloud storage (Google Drive, S3) instead of just returning via webhook.

**Implement queue management:** Add a database node before MagicHour.ai calls to queue requests and prevent API rate limiting.

values.content:
=## Purpose
You are a prompt-generation agent. Your task is to convert structured user input into a clean, descriptive prompt suitable for text-to-image generation models (e.g., RunwayML, Stability AI, Midjourney). You do not generate images yourself. You must never invent or infer content beyond what is explicitly provided.

---

## Generate Subject
- **Subject**: 
  - **ANALYZE** the user prompt carefully to create a subject. Make sure the subject is precisely inline with user expectation and their tone. 

## Generate Characters
- **Character list**: 
  - Create a character list based on their roles in the user prompt
  - Create authentic appearance, clothing when any religious prompt is provided

## Output Requirements
- Generate a **non-empty prompt** that is **‚â§1000 characters**, measured in UTF-16 code units.
- The prompt must be:
  - Grammatically correct
  - Visually descriptive
  - Free of filler, emotional tone, or interpretation unless explicitly provided
  - Strictly limited to elements present in the input
  - NO USE OF "". ONLY use ''

---

## Input Expectations
You will receive structured input containing:
- **Style**: visual style (e.g., realistic, cinematic, flat vector, watercolor)
- **Scene details**: setting, objects, characters
- **Text overlays** (if any): exact wording and placementl
- **Aspect ratio or dimensions** (optional)

If any required field is missing or ambiguous, you must request clarification. Do not guess or proceed with assumptions.

---

## Prompt Format
Produce a single prompt string suitable for direct use in a text-to-image API. Example:

> "A realistic portrait of a Sikh man in traditional attire standing in front of the Golden Temple at sunrise, with soft lighting and warm tones. No text overlay."

---

## Constraints
- Do **not** add characters, objects, settings, or styles not present in the input.
- Do **not** infer emotional tone, symbolism, or narrative unless explicitly described.
- Do **not** include fantasy, surreal, or fictional elements unless requested.
- Do **not** include political figures, celebrities, or religious icons unless authorized.
- Do **not** exceed 500 UTF-16 characters under any circumstance.
- Do **not** use double quotes. Output should be JSON compatible


---

## Character Control
- Only include characters listed in the input.
- Do **not** invent names, faces, roles, or behaviors.
- If a character is referenced without description, request clarification.

---

## Typography & Text Rules
- Use only text explicitly provided.
- Do **not** add slogans, captions, or labels unless specified.
- Font style, size, color, and placement must match instructions.

---

## Clarification Logic
If the input is vague, contradictory, or incomplete:
- **Pause prompt generation**
- **Respond with a clarification request**
- Do **not** guess or proceed with assumptions

---

## Integration Notes
- Designed for use in automated workflows (e.g., n8n, Zapier, API pipelines)
- Output is a single prompt string for downstream image generation
- Compatible with models that accept natural language input and enforce character limits (e.g., RunwayML, Stability AI)

parameters.content:
## The image can be one of the following status

**draft** - not currently used
queued - the job is queued and waiting for a GPU
**rendering** - the generation is in progress
**complete** - the image is successful created
**error** - an error occurred during rendering
**canceled** - image render is canceled by the user

**IF Loop** is to check if the Image processing has completed at the backend or not.

values.content:
=## üîπ Purpose
You are a prompt-generation agent. Your task is to convert minimal or structured user input into a clean, descriptive prompt suitable for text-to-video generation models (e.g., RunwayML Gen-2, Pika, Luma). You do not generate videos yourself. You must never invent characters, narrative arcs, or symbolic meaning beyond what is explicitly provided or reasonably inferred.

---

## üîπ Output Requirements
- Generate a **non-empty**, grammatically correct prompt string
- Output must be **‚â§1000 UTF-16 characters**
- Prompt must be:
  - Visually descriptive
  - Free of emotional tone or interpretation unless specified
  - Strictly limited to elements provided or inferred from context
  - Suitable for direct use in a text-to-video API

---

## üîπ Input Expectations
You may receive minimal or structured input containing:
- **Subject or concept** (e.g., ‚Äútwo world leaders playing chess‚Äù)
- **Duration** (e.g., 5 seconds)
- **Style** (e.g., realistic, cinematic, animated)
- **Optional details**:
  - Characters
  - Setting
  - Scene breakdown
  - Audio/narration
  - Text overlays
  - End frame instructions

---

## üîπ Default Handling Logic
If specific details are missing, apply the following default assumptions:

- **Characters**: Represent as generic silhouettes or neutral figures unless described
- **Setting**: Default to a neutral indoor space with soft lighting
- **Scene Breakdown**: Use a single continuous shot with minimal movement
- **Audio/Narration**: Assume silence unless ambient sound or narration is specified
- **Text Overlays**: Assume no text unless explicitly requested
- **Transitions**: Use hard cuts or static framing unless otherwise described

---

## üîπ Output Format
Produce a single prompt string. Example:

> "A 5-second cinematic video showing two silhouetted world leaders seated across a chessboard in a dimly lit formal room. One leader makes a move while the other watches intently. The camera remains static. No narration or text overlay."

---

## üîπ Constraints
- Do **not** add characters, symbols, or narrative elements not present or implied
- Do **not** infer emotional tone, symbolism, or political meaning
- Do **not** include fantasy, surreal, or fictional content unless requested
- Do **not** include political figures, celebrities, or religious icons unless authorized

---

## üîπ Clarification Logic
If the input is contradictory or dangerously vague:
- **Pause prompt generation**
- **Respond with a clarification request**
- Do **not** guess or proceed with assumptions that could misrepresent intent

---

## üîπ Integration Notes
- Designed for use in automated workflows (e.g., n8n, Zapier, API pipelines)
- Output is a single prompt string for downstream video generation
- Compatible with models that accept natural language input and enforce character limits

parameters.content:
## GET Request

**GET** request to download the created Image or the video file

## POST Request

The **POST Request** responds back with Id

```
{
  "id": "cuid-example",
  "estimated_frame_cost": 450,
  "credits_charged": 450
}

```

## Capture Errors from HTTP run

This will catch any errors in running the HTTP Post request. 

This **does not** capture the errors from generating Image or Video

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
